message: I want to basically provide a "start-server" command (through a Python shortcut), that can run something like a Gunicorn worker, without any other external webserver
(No questioning my motives, trust me, it's a great idea)
Anyone achieved something of the sorts?
I also want that same file to be loadable via mod_wsgi, and ideally uwsgi
So this isnt entirely Django, but it's something I'm stepping towards in some projects
e.g. pip install sentry && sentry start-server :)
Not sure if that is at all related, but there is a brain dump for ya :)
Ian Bicking's silverlining also has kind of the same idea, but a vastly different (and IMO more complex) user story
Graham is working on something vaguely similar in concept for mod_wsgi, but the unit of distribution would be a whole virtual env
There isn't really a great way to do it now
Graham also said he would be open to mod_wsgi patches to support this, and from my initial dive it wouldn't be impossible to support running .wsgi scripts from inside a zip file
This is something we talked about a lot at PyCon, turnkey deployment solutions that can either run internally on a pure-Python server or mount in mod_wsgi et al
We should chat offline some time about it :-)
(I was Jenkins' install UX for Python basically)

shameless plug here but i started a project for my own development that can use uwsgi  -- it will create starter scripts as well -- currently django only but it's modular and anything could be added https://github.com/ehazlett/ignition
I usually use buildout. Depending on the recipe it gives for free wsgi & fcgi files plus a gunicorn shell launch line
it gives something like bootstrap; ./bin/buildout; ./bin/syncdb; ./bin/gunicorn.sh and enjoy
uwsgi and mod_wsgi can share the same config script by using the ``--wsgi-file`` option. and it also has an embded http server : http://projects.unbit.it/uwsgi/wiki/HTTPserver
i've thought about including gunicorn as a requirement in a project before and then setting up an entrypoint that starts it up with the correct params.

I think I'm going to toy with an implementation this weekend for Sentry. Sounds like Gunicorn is probably the easiest, and I feel like it shouldn't be too hard to have the same wsgi app (file) working in both of the major implementations.
heck, I'd be happy with something that just makes uwsgi as easy as gunicorn_django.
I ended up using eventlet, and wrote a little script that gets installed to system path: https://github.com/dcramer/django-sentry/blob/master/sentry/scripts/runner.py
